column2: '21Oct'
column3: 1)	" I believe that the question oversimplifies the difficulties of what we must do in Central America. Our objectives ought to be to strengthen the democracies
column4: to stop Communist and other extremist influences
column5: and stabilize the community in that area. To do that we need a three-pronged attack: one is military assistance to our friends who are being pressured; secondly
column6: a strong and sophisticated economic aid program and human rights program that offers a better life and a sharper alternative to the alternative offered by the totalitarians who oppose us; and finally
column7: a strong diplomatic effort that pursues the possibilities of peace in the area. That's one of the big disagreements that we have with the President -- that they have not pursued the diplomatic opportunities either within El Salvador or as between the countries and have lost time during which we might have been able to achieve a peace  This brings up the whole question of what Presidential leadership is all about. I think the lesson in Central America
column8: this recent embarrassment in Nicaragua where we are giving instructions for hired assassins
column9: hiring criminals
column10: and the rest -- all of this has strengthened our opponents.  A President must not only assure that we're tough
column11: but we must also be wise and smart in the exercise of that power. We saw the same thing in Lebanon
column12: where we spent a good deal of America's assets. But because the leadership of this government did not pursue wise policies
column13: we have been humiliated
column14: and our opponents are stronger.  The bottom line of national strength is that the President must be in command
column15: he must lead. And when a President doesn't know that submarine missiles are recallable
column16: says that 70 percent of our strategic forces are conventional
column17: discovers 3 years into his administration that our arms control efforts have failed because he didn't know that most Soviet missiles were on land -- these are things a President must know to command.  A President is called the Commander in Chief. And he's called that because he's supposed to be in charge of the facts and run our government and strengthen our nation.

column1: We absolutely must
column2: which is why I responded to your first question the way I did. It's much more complex. You must understand the region; you must understand the politics in the area; you must provide a strong alternative; and you must show strength -- and all at the same time. That's why I object to the covert action in Nicaragua. That's a classic example of a strategy that's embarrassed us
column3: strengthened our opposition
column4: and undermined the moral authority of our people and our country in the region. Strength requires knowledge
column5: command. We've seen in the Nicaraguan example a policy that has actually hurt us
column6: strengthened our opposition
column7: and undermined the moral authority of our country in that region.

column1: No
column2: but I'm glad you asked that question
column3: because I know it's on many peoples' minds. I have ordered an investigation. I know that the CIA is already going forward with one. We have a gentleman down in Nicaragua who is on contract to the CIA
column4: advising -- supposedly on military tactics -- the contras. And he drew up this manual. It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed. And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there
column5: the man in charge
column6: and he sent it on up here to CIA
column7: where more pages were excised before it was printed. But some way or other
column8: there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA. Now
column9: those are the details as we have them. And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed
column10: we certainly are going to do something about that. We'll take the proper action at the proper time.  I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there
column11: and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr. Mondale in complete agreement with what we're doing
column12: because the plan that he has outlined is the one we've been following for quite some time
column13: including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group.  So
column14: I can only tell you about the manual -- that we're not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt. But if guilt is established
column15: whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then
column16: and they will be removed.

column1: I'm afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua. There's not someone there directing all of this activity. There are
column2: as you know
column3: CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and
column4: certainly
column5: in Central America. And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to
column6: and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order
column7: in December of 1981
column8: that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations.

column1: What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office? He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land. A President can't know everything
column2: but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws. This manual -- several thousands of which were produced -- was distributed
column3: ordering political assassinations
column4: hiring of criminals
column5: and other forms of terrorism. Some of it was excised
column6: but the part dealing with political terrorism was continued. How can this happen? How can something this serious occur in an administration and have a President of the United States in a situation like this say he didn't know? A President must know these things. I don't know which is worse
column7: not knowing or knowing and not stopping it.  And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law? This has hurt this country
column8: and a President's supposed to command.

column1: Yes. I have so many things there to respond to
column2: I'm going to pick out something you said earlier. You've been all over the country repeating something that
column3: I will admit
column4: the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back. I never
column5: ever conceived of such a thing. I never said any such thing. In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations
column6: I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons
column7: not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles
column8: and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change
column9: you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.  But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing
column10: which is absolutely false. How anyone could think that any sane person would believe you could call back a nuclear missile
column11: I think is as ridiculous as the whole concept has been. So
column12: thank you for giving me a chance to straighten the record. I'm sure that you appreciate that. [Laughter]

'But because the leadership of this government did not pursue wise policies, we have been humiliated, and our opponents are stronger', 'The bottom line of national strength is that the President must be in command, he must lead', 'And when a President doesnt know that submarine missiles are recallable, says that 70 percent of our strategic forces are conventional, discovers 3 years into his 'It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed', 'And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there, the man in charge, and he sent it on up here to CIA, where more pages were excised before it was printed', 'But some way or other, there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA', 'Now, those are the details as we have them', 'And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed, we certainly are going to do something about that', 'Well take the proper action at the proper time', 'I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there, and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr Mondale in complete agreement with what were doing, because the plan that he has outlined is the one weve been following for quite some time, including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group', 'So, I can only tell you about the manual  that were not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt', 'But if guilt is established, whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then, and they will be removed', 'Im afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua', 'Theres not someone there directing all of this activity', 'There are, as you know, CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and, certainly, in Central America', 'And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to, and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order, in December of 1981, that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations', 'What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office?', 'He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land', 'A President cant know everything, but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws', 'This manual  several thousands of which were produced  was distributed, ordering political assassinations, hiring of criminals, and other forms of terrorism', 'Some of it was excised, but the this say he didnt know?', 'A President must know these things', 'I dont know which is worse, not knowing or knowing and not stopping it', 'And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law?', 'This has hurt this country, and a Presidents supposed to command', 'Yes', 'I have so many things there to respond to, Im going to pick out something you said earlier', 'Youve been all over the country repeating something that, I will admit, the press has also been repeating  that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back', 'I never, ever conceived of such a thing', 'I never said any such thing', 'In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations, I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventionaltype weapons, not as destabilizing as the landbased missiles, and that they were also weapons that  or carriers  that if they were sent out and there was a change, you could call them back before they had launched their missiles', 'But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing, which is absolutely false', 'How anyone could think that any sane person column2: '21Oct'
column3: 1)	" I believe that the question oversimplifies the difficulties of what we must do in Central America. Our objectives ought to be to strengthen the democracies
column4: to stop Communist and other extremist influences
column5: and stabilize the community in that area. To do that we need a three-pronged attack: one is military assistance to our friends who are being pressured; secondly
column6: a strong and sophisticated economic aid program and human rights program that offers a better life and a sharper alternative to the alternative offered by the totalitarians who oppose us; and finally
column7: a strong diplomatic effort that pursues the possibilities of peace in the area. That's one of the big disagreements that we have with the President -- that they have not pursued the diplomatic opportunities either within El Salvador or as between the countries and have lost time during which we might have been able to achieve a peace  This brings up the whole question of what Presidential leadership is all about. I think the lesson in Central America
column8: this recent embarrassment in Nicaragua where we are giving instructions for hired assassins
column9: hiring criminals
column10: and the rest -- all of this has strengthened our opponents.  A President must not only assure that we're tough
column11: but we must also be wise and smart in the exercise of that power. We saw the same thing in Lebanon
column12: where we spent a good deal of America's assets. But because the leadership of this government did not pursue wise policies
column13: we have been humiliated
column14: and our opponents are stronger.  The bottom line of national strength is that the President must be in command
column15: he must lead. And when a President doesn't know that submarine missiles are recallable
column16: says that 70 percent of our strategic forces are conventional
column17: discovers 3 years into his administration that our arms control efforts have failed because he didn't know that most Soviet missiles were on land -- these are things a President must know to command.  A President is called the Commander in Chief. And he's called that because he's supposed to be in charge of the facts and run our government and strengthen our nation.

column1: We absolutely must
column2: which is why I responded to your first question the way I did. It's much more complex. You must understand the region; you must understand the politics in the area; you must provide a strong alternative; and you must show strength -- and all at the same time. That's why I object to the covert action in Nicaragua. That's a classic example of a strategy that's embarrassed us
column3: strengthened our opposition
column4: and undermined the moral authority of our people and our country in the region. Strength requires knowledge
column5: command. We've seen in the Nicaraguan example a policy that has actually hurt us
column6: strengthened our opposition
column7: and undermined the moral authority of our country in that region.

column1: No
column2: but I'm glad you asked that question
column3: because I know it's on many peoples' minds. I have ordered an investigation. I know that the CIA is already going forward with one. We have a gentleman down in Nicaragua who is on contract to the CIA
column4: advising -- supposedly on military tactics -- the contras. And he drew up this manual. It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed. And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there
column5: the man in charge
column6: and he sent it on up here to CIA
column7: where more pages were excised before it was printed. But some way or other
column8: there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA. Now
column9: those are the details as we have them. And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed
column10: we certainly are going to do something about that. We'll take the proper action at the proper time.  I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there
column11: and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr. Mondale in complete agreement with what we're doing
column12: because the plan that he has outlined is the one we've been following for quite some time
column13: including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group.  So
column14: I can only tell you about the manual -- that we're not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt. But if guilt is established
column15: whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then
column16: and they will be removed.

column1: I'm afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua. There's not someone there directing all of this activity. There are
column2: as you know
column3: CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and
column4: certainly
column5: in Central America. And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to
column6: and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order
column7: in December of 1981
column8: that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations.

column1: What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office? He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land. A President can't know everything
column2: but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws. This manual -- several thousands of which were produced -- was distributed
column3: ordering political assassinations
column4: hiring of criminals
column5: and other forms of terrorism. Some of it was excised
column6: but the part dealing with political terrorism was continued. How can this happen? How can something this serious occur in an administration and have a President of the United States in a situation like this say he didn't know? A President must know these things. I don't know which is worse
column7: not knowing or knowing and not stopping it.  And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law? This has hurt this country
column8: and a President's supposed to command.

column1: Yes. I have so many things there to respond to
column2: I'm going to pick out something you said earlier. You've been all over the country repeating something that
column3: I will admit
column4: the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back. I never
column5: ever conceived of such a thing. I never said any such thing. In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations
column6: I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons
column7: not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles
column8: and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change
column9: you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.  But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing
column10: which is absolutely false. How anyone could think that any sane person would believe you could call back a nuclear missile
column11: I think is as ridiculous as the whole concept has been. So
column12: thank you for giving me a chance to straighten the record. I'm sure that you appreciate that. [Laughter]

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 1)	" I believe that the question oversimplifies the difficulties of what we must do in Central America. Our objectives ought to be to strengthen the democracies
column4: to stop Communist and other extremist influences
column5: and stabilize the community in that area. To do that we need a three-pronged attack: one is military assistance to our friends who are being pressured; secondly
column6: a strong and sophisticated economic aid program and human rights program that offers a better life and a sharper alternative to the alternative offered by the totalitarians who oppose us; and finally
column7: a strong diplomatic effort that pursues the possibilities of peace in the area. That's one of the big disagreements that we have with the President -- that they have not pursued the diplomatic opportunities either within El Salvador or as between the countries and have lost time during which we might have been able to achieve a peace  This brings up the whole question of what Presidential leadership is all about. I think the lesson in Central America
column8: this recent embarrassment in Nicaragua where we are giving instructions for hired assassins
column9: hiring criminals
column10: and the rest -- all of this has strengthened our opponents.  A President must not only assure that we're tough
column11: but we must also be wise and smart in the exercise of that power. We saw the same thing in Lebanon
column12: where we spent a good deal of America's assets. But because the leadership of this government did not pursue wise policies
column13: we have been humiliated
column14: and our opponents are stronger.  The bottom line of national strength is that the President must be in command
column15: he must lead. And when a President doesn't know that submarine missiles are recallable
column16: says that 70 percent of our strategic forces are conventional
column17: discovers 3 years into his administration that our arms control efforts have failed because he didn't know that most Soviet missiles were on land -- these are things a President must know to command.  A President is called the Commander in Chief. And he's called that because he's supposed to be in charge of the facts and run our government and strengthen our nation.

column1: We absolutely must
column2: which is why I responded to your first question the way I did. It's much more complex. You must understand the region; you must understand the politics in the area; you must provide a strong alternative; and you must show strength -- and all at the same time. That's why I object to the covert action in Nicaragua. That's a classic example of a strategy that's embarrassed us
column3: strengthened our opposition
column4: and undermined the moral authority of our people and our country in the region. Strength requires knowledge
column5: command. We've seen in the Nicaraguan example a policy that has actually hurt us
column6: strengthened our opposition
column7: and undermined the moral authority of our country in that region.

column1: No
column2: but I'm glad you asked that question
column3: because I know it's on many peoples' minds. I have ordered an investigation. I know that the CIA is already going forward with one. We have a gentleman down in Nicaragua who is on contract to the CIA
column4: advising -- supposedly on military tactics -- the contras. And he drew up this manual. It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed. And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there
column5: the man in charge
column6: and he sent it on up here to CIA
column7: where more pages were excised before it was printed. But some way or other
column8: there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA. Now
column9: those are the details as we have them. And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed
column10: we certainly are going to do something about that. We'll take the proper action at the proper time.  I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there
column11: and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr. Mondale in complete agreement with what we're doing
column12: because the plan that he has outlined is the one we've been following for quite some time
column13: including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group.  So
column14: I can only tell you about the manual -- that we're not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt. But if guilt is established
column15: whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then
column16: and they will be removed.

column1: I'm afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua. There's not someone there directing all of this activity. There are
column2: as you know
column3: CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and
column4: certainly
column5: in Central America. And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to
column6: and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order
column7: in December of 1981
column8: that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations.

column1: What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office? He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land. A President can't know everything
column2: but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws. This manual -- several thousands of which were produced -- was distributed
column3: ordering political assassinations
column4: hiring of criminals
column5: and other forms of terrorism. Some of it was excised
column6: but the part dealing with political terrorism was continued. How can this happen? How can something this serious occur in an administration and have a President of the United States in a situation like this say he didn't know? A President must know these things. I don't know which is worse
column7: not knowing or knowing and not stopping it.  And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law? This has hurt this country
column8: and a President's supposed to command.

column1: Yes. I have so many things there to respond to
column2: I'm going to pick out something you said earlier. You've been all over the country repeating something that
column3: I will admit
column4: the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back. I never
column5: ever conceived of such a thing. I never said any such thing. In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations
column6: I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons
column7: not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles
column8: and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change
column9: you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.  But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing
column10: which is absolutely false. How anyone could think that any sane person would believe you could call back a nuclear missile
column11: I think is as ridiculous as the whole concept has been. So
column12: thank you for giving me a chance to straighten the record. I'm sure that you appreciate that. [Laughter]

column17: discovers 3 years into his administration that our arms control efforts have failed because he didn't know that most Soviet missiles were on land -- these are things a President must know to command.  A President is called the Commander in Chief. And he's called that because he's supposed to be in charge of the facts and run our government and strengthen our nation.

column1: We absolutely must
column2: which is why I responded to your first question the way I did. It's much more complex. You must understand the region; you must understand the politics in the area; you must provide a strong alternative; and you must show strength -- and all at the same time. That's why I object to the covert action in Nicaragua. That's a classic example of a strategy that's embarrassed us
column3: strengthened our opposition
column4: and undermined the moral authority of our people and our country in the region. Strength requires knowledge
column5: command. We've seen in the Nicaraguan example a policy that has actually hurt us
column6: strengthened our opposition
column7: and undermined the moral authority of our country in that region.

column1: No
column2: but I'm glad you asked that question
column3: because I know it's on many peoples' minds. I have ordered an investigation. I know that the CIA is already going forward with one. We have a gentleman down in Nicaragua who is on contract to the CIA
column4: advising -- supposedly on military tactics -- the contras. And he drew up this manual. It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed. And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there
column5: the man in charge
column6: and he sent it on up here to CIA
column7: where more pages were excised before it was printed. But some way or other
column8: there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA. Now
column9: those are the details as we have them. And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed
column10: we certainly are going to do something about that. We'll take the proper action at the proper time.  I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there
column11: and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr. Mondale in complete agreement with what we're doing
column12: because the plan that he has outlined is the one we've been following for quite some time
column13: including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group.  So
column14: I can only tell you about the manual -- that we're not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt. But if guilt is established
column15: whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then
column16: and they will be removed.

column1: I'm afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua. There's not someone there directing all of this activity. There are
column2: as you know
column3: CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and
column4: certainly
column5: in Central America. And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to
column6: and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order
column7: in December of 1981
column8: that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations.

column1: What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office? He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land. A President can't know everything
column2: but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws. This manual -- several thousands of which were produced -- was distributed
column3: ordering political assassinations
column4: hiring of criminals
column5: and other forms of terrorism. Some of it was excised
column6: but the part dealing with political terrorism was continued. How can this happen? How can something this serious occur in an administration and have a President of the United States in a situation like this say he didn't know? A President must know these things. I don't know which is worse
column7: not knowing or knowing and not stopping it.  And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law? This has hurt this country
column8: and a President's supposed to command.

column1: Yes. I have so many things there to respond to
column2: I'm going to pick out something you said earlier. You've been all over the country repeating something that
column3: I will admit
column4: the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back. I never
column5: ever conceived of such a thing. I never said any such thing. In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations
column6: I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons
column7: not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles
column8: and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change
column9: you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.  But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing
column10: which is absolutely false. How anyone could think that any sane person would believe you could call back a nuclear missile
column11: I think is as ridiculous as the whole concept has been. So
column12: thank you for giving me a chance to straighten the record. I'm sure that you appreciate that. [Laughter]

column7: a strong diplomatic effort that pursues the possibilities of peace in the area.'

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column1: Ah
column2: well
column3: now you've added a hypothetical there at the end
column4: Mr. Kalb
column5: about where we would send troops in to fight. I am not going to make the decision as to what the tactics could be
column6: but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us. One is the Middle East
column7: and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations
column8: because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there. Our neighbors here in America are vital to us. We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates
column9: the thousands of them
column10: from Angola. So
column11: I can say there are a great many interests. I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin. That is where I think the future of the world lies. But I am not going to pick out one and
column12: in advance
column13: hypothetically say
column14: ""Oh
column15: yes
column16: we would send troops there.'' I don't want to send troops any place.

column1: All right.  Soviet Union
Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups
column4: wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms. I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state. They are a tough and a ruthless adversary
column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups

column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to

column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column1: Ah
column2: well
column3: now you've added a hypothetical there at the end
column4: Mr. Kalb
column5: about where we would send troops in to fight. I am not going to make the decision as to what the tactics could be
column6: but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us. One is the Middle East
column7: and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations
column8: because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there. Our neighbors here in America are vital to us. We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates
column9: the thousands of them
column10: from Angola. So
column11: I can say there are a great many interests. I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin. That is where I think the future of the world lies. But I am not going to pick out one and
column12: in advance
column13: hypothetically say
column14: ""Oh
column15: yes
column16: we would send troops there.'' I don't want to send troops any place.

column1: All right.  Soviet Union
Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups
column4: wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms. I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state. They are a tough and a ruthless adversary
column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column1: Ah
column2: well
column3: now you've added a hypothetical there at the end
column4: Mr. Kalb
column5: about where we would send troops in to fight. I am not going to make the decision as to what the tactics could be
column6: but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us. One is the Middle East
column7: and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations
column8: because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there. Our neighbors here in America are vital to us. We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates
column9: the thousands of them
column10: from Angola. So
column11: I can say there are a great many interests. I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin. That is where I think the future of the world lies. But I am not going to pick out one and
column12: in advance
column13: hypothetically say
column14: ""Oh
column15: yes
column16: we would send troops there.'' I don't want to send troops any place.

column1: All right.  Soviet Union
Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups
column4: wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms. I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state. They are a tough and a ruthless adversary
column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank

column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column6: but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us. One is the Middle East
column7: and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations
column8: because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there. Our neighbors here in America are vital to us. We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates
column9: the thousands of them
column10: from Angola. So
column11: I can say there are a great many interests. I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin. That is where I think the future of the world lies. But I am not going to pick out one and

column13: hypothetically say
