column1: All right.  Soviet Union
Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups
column4: wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms. I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state. They are a tough and a ruthless adversary
column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 2)	" I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union. I retract nothing that I have said. I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have. But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world
column4: we have to live with each other. And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system. They don't like ours. And we're not going to change their system
column5: and they sure better not try to change ours. But between us
column6: we can either destroy the world or we can save it. And I suggested that
column7: certainly
column8: it was to their common interest
column9: along with ours
column10: to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons. And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding. I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic. I know that Mr. Mondale
column11: in the past
column12: has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves
column13: and if we were kind and good and did something nice
column14: they would respond accordingly. And the result was unilateral disarmament. We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration. What did we get for it? Nothing.  The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament
column15: of weakness
column16: if you will. And now we are putting up a defense of our own. And I've made it very plain to them
column17: we seek no superiority. We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us. Now
column18: they claim they're not. And I made it plain to them
column19: we're not. There's been no change in my attitude at all. I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union. And we did get their attention.   Regions Vital to U.S. Interests

column1: Ah
column2: well
column3: now you've added a hypothetical there at the end
column4: Mr. Kalb
column5: about where we would send troops in to fight. I am not going to make the decision as to what the tactics could be
column6: but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us. One is the Middle East
column7: and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations
column8: because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there. Our neighbors here in America are vital to us. We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates
column9: the thousands of them
column10: from Angola. So
column11: I can say there are a great many interests. I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin. That is where I think the future of the world lies. But I am not going to pick out one and
column12: in advance
column13: hypothetically say
column14: ""Oh
column15: yes
column16: we would send troops there.'' I don't want to send troops any place.

column1: All right.  Soviet Union
Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined
column2: so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification
column3: which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups
column4: wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms. I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state. They are a tough and a ruthless adversary
column5: and we must be prepared to meet that challenge
column6: and I would. Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must
column7: as past Presidents before this one have done
column8: meet on the common ground of survival. And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement
column9: by every President
column10: of both political parties
column11: since the bomb went off. And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all
column12: but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead. There are now over 2
column13: 000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in
column14: and that does not strengthen us.  We must be very
column15: very realistic in the nature of that leadership
column16: but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences
column17: particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.  There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration. I will keep this nation strong. I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to
column18: but that
column19: too
column20: is a part of national strength. To do that
column21: a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.  And that's where the President's failure to master
column22: in my opinion
column23: the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly. He's 3 years into this administration. He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land
column24: and that's why his proposal didn't work.  I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said. He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them
column25: and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.

column1: A President must know those things.  Eastern Europe

I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe. We ought to deal with each of these countries separately. We ought to pursue strategies with each of them
column2: economic and the rest
column3: that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union. Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly
column4: as they have in many of those countries
column5: especially
column6: recently
column7: in Poland
column8: I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate. Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility. That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.

column1: Yes. I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here. But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong
column2: as he said he would be
column3: I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off. And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned
column4: he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it. [Laughter] He was against the F - 14 fighter
column5: he was against the M - 1 tank
column6: he was against the B - 1 bomber
column7: he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military
column8: he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe. And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.

column1: Indeed
column2: he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate. And he opposed even President Carter
column3: when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.

column1: Mr. President
column2: I accept your commitment to peace
column3: but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense. [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength
column4: in real terms
column5: by double that of the Soviet Union. I'll tell you where we disagree. It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14
column6: and I'll tell you why. The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.  Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department. My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense. There's a big difference between the two of us. A President must manage that budget. I will keep us strong
column7: but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need. You pay $500 for a $5 hammer
column8: you're not buying strength.

column3: 3)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country. And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America. In Lebanon
column5: this President exercised American power
column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column4: I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country. And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America. In Lebanon
column5: this President exercised American power
column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column3: 3)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country. And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America. In Lebanon
column5: this President exercised American power
column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column3: 3)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country. And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America. In Lebanon
column5: this President exercised American power
column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column3: 3)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country. And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America. In Lebanon
column5: this President exercised American power
column6: all right
column7: but the management of it was such that our marines were killed
column8: we had to leave in humiliation
column9: the Soviet Union became stronger
column10: terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised
column11: did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked
column12: that we ended up the way we did.  Similarly
column13: in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress
column14: including many Republicans
column15: have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us
column16: where we get associated with political assassins and the rest. We have to decline
column17: for the first time in modern history
column18: jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions. And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.  We need to be strong
column19: we need to be prepared to use that strength
column20: but we must understand that we are a democracy. We are a government by the people
column21: and when we move
column22: it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us. It is only in that way that we can persevere.   Nicaragua

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.
