column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: In Lebanon, this President exercised American power, all right, but the management of it was such that our marines were killed, we had to leave in humiliation, the Soviet Union became stronger, terrorists became emboldened. And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised, did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked, that we ended up the way we did. column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation

column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border
column7: to take those steps
column8: whatever they might be
column9: to stop it. The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation
column10: not interfere in other nations. And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said
column11: they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger
column12: because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.   Lebanon

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty
column2: the so-called Rio Pact
column3: that permits the nations
column4: our friends in that region
column5: to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua
column6: when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border

column1: No
column2: Morton
column3: I don't agree to all of those things. First of all
column4: when we and our allies -- the Italians
column5: the French
column6: and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon
column7: we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government. But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in
column8: we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists. Israel could not be blamed for that. Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently
column9: and Israel chased them all the way to there.  Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove
column10: and did remove
column11: more than 13
column12: 000 of those terrorists from Lebanon. We departed. And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.  And we were succeeding. We were there for the better part of a year. Our position happened to be at the airport. Oh
column13: there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire
column14: but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission. I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them
column15: they can darn well shoot back. And this is what we did. We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.  But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember
column16: there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan. We were succeeding
column17: and that was why the terrorist acts began. There are forces there -- and that includes Syria
column18: in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed
column19: who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon
column20: dominant over its own territory. And so
column21: the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building. Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in. But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them. And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.

column1: Morton
column2: no. I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel
column3: and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on. In the terrorist situation
column4: there are terrorist factions all over. In a recent 30-day period
column5: 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed. The most recent has been the one in Brighton. In dealing with terrorists
column6: yes
column7: we want to retaliate
column8: but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating. I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal
column9: along with our allies
column10: with this terrorist problem. And it's going to take all the nations together
column11: just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.  Well
column12: the red light went on. I could have gone on forever.

column1: Groucho Marx said
column2: ""Who do you believe? -- me
column3: or your own eyes?'' And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen. The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible. They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said
column4: ""Please
column5: take them out of there.'' The Secretary of State admitted that this morning. He did not do so. The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken. That was the second time. Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago
column6: and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken. And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way
column7: and they weren't taken. The terrorists have won each time. The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate. He didn't. They called their bluff. And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation
column8: and our enemies are stronger.

column1: Yes. First of all
column2: Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks. That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there. That is one. On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists
column3: I'm tempted to ask you what you would do. These are unidentified people
column4: and after the bomb goes off
column5: they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it. We are going to
column6: as I say
column7: we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from
column8: and retaliation will be taken. But we're not going to simply kill some people to say
column9: ""Oh
column10: look
column11: we got even.'' We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts. And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.

column1: No. And I have not made it an issue

column4: and make the decisions and the judgments that are necessary. A minute ago the President quoted Cicero

column23: we're completing 4 years. This is the first administration since the bomb went off that made no progress. We have an arms race underway instead.  A President has to lead his government or it won't be done. Different people with different views fight with each other. For 3\1/2\ years
column25: resisted tabling arms control proposals that had any hope of agreeing

column31: '' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others

column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column1: Yes
column2: this had to do with our disarmament talks. And the whole controversy about land missiles came up because we thought that the strategic nuclear weapons
column3: the most destabilizing are the land-based. You put your thumb on a button and somebody blows up 20 minutes later. So

column5: a second phase
column6: take up the submarine-launched or the airborne missiles. The Soviet Union
column7: to our surprise -- and not just mine -- made it plain when we brought this up that they placed
column8: they thought
column9: a greater reliance on the land-based missiles and
column10: therefore

column12: ""All right
column13: if that's what you want to do.'' But it was a surprise to us
column14: because they outnumbered us 64 to 36 in submarines and 20 percent more bombers capable of carrying nuclear missiles than we had. So

column19: I'm going to hang in there. Should the President's age and stamina be an issue in the political campaign?

column1: No. And I have not made it an issue
column2: nor should it be. What's at issue here is the President's application of his authority to understand what a President must know to lead this nation
column3: secure our defense
column4: and make the decisions and the judgments that are necessary. A minute ago the President quoted Cicero
column5: I believe. I want to quote somebody a little closer to home
column6: Harry Truman. He said
column7: ""The buck stops here.'' We just heard the President's answer for the problems at the barracks in Lebanon
column8: where 241 marines were killed. What happened? First
column9: the Joint Chiefs of Staff went to the President
column10: said
column11: ""Don't put those troops there.'' They did it. And then 5 days before the troops were killed
column12: they went back to the President
column13: through the Secretary of Defense
column14: and said
column15: ""Please
column16: Mr. President
column17: take those troops out of there because we can't defend them.'' They didn't do it. And we know what happened.  After that
column18: once again
column19: our Embassy was exploded. This is the fourth time this has happened -- an identical attack
column21: despite warnings -- even public warnings -- from the terrorists. Who's in charge? Who's handling this matter? That's my main point.  Now
column22: on arms control
column23: we're completing 4 years. This is the first administration since the bomb went off that made no progress. We have an arms race underway instead.  A President has to lead his government or it won't be done. Different people with different views fight with each other. For 3\1/2\ years
column25: resisted tabling arms control proposals that had any hope of agreeing
column26: rebuked their negotiator in 1981 when he came close to an agreement
column28: on medium-range weapons. And we have this arms race underway. And a recent book that just came out by perhaps the Nation's most respected author in this field
column30: called ""Deadly Gambits
column31: '' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us
column32: both in terms of security and terms of arms control. That's why they call the President the Commander in Chief.  Good intentions
column33: I grant. But it takes more than that. You must be tough and smart.   The President's Leadership  Mr. Trewhitt. This question of leadership keeps arising in different forms in this discussion already. And the President
column35: has called you whining and vacillating
column36: among the more charitable phrases -- weak
column37: I believe. It is a question of leadership. And he has made the point that you have not repudiated some of the semidiplomatic activity of the Reverend Jackson
column38: particularly in Central America. Did you approve of his diplomatic activity? And are you prepared to repudiate him now?

column1: I read his statement the other day. I don't admire Fidel Castro at all. And I've said that. Che Guevara was a contemptible figure in civilization's history. I know the Cuban state as a police state
column2: and all my life I've worked in a way that demonstrates that. But Jesse Jackson is an independent person. I don't control him. And let's talk about people we do control. In the last debate
column3: \1\ (FOOTNOTE) the Vice President of the United States said that I said the marines had died shamefully and died in shame in Lebanon. I demanded an apology from Vice President Bush because I had

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale
column2: but I am in charge. And
column3: as a matter of fact
column4: we haven't avoided arms control talks with the Soviet Union. Very early in my administration I proposed -- and I think something that had never been proposed by any previous administration -- I proposed a total elimination of intermediate-range missiles
column5: where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe. When they protested that and suggested a smaller number
column6: perhaps
column7: I went along with that. The so-called negotiation that you said I walked out on was the so-called walk in the woods between one of our representatives and one of the Soviet Union
column8: and it wasn't me that turned it down
column9: the Soviet Union disavowed it.

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others
column2: but two that I want to cite tonight. One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book
column3: ""Deadly Gambits.'' The other is John Neuhaus
column4: who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country. Both said that this administration turned down the ""walk in the woods'' agreement first
column5: and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security. When Mr. Nitze
column6: a good negotiator
column7: returned
column8: he was rebuked
column9: and his boss was fired. This is the kind of leadership that we've had in this administration on the most deadly issue of our times. Now we have a runaway arms race. All they've got to show for 4 years in U.S.-Soviet relations is one meeting in the last weeks of an administration
column10: and nothing before.  They're tough negotiators
column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column11: I don't know which
column12: that said

column14: there would be no state.''  Strategic Missiles  Mr. Trewhitt. Mr. President
column15: I'd like to head for the fence and try to catch that one before it goes over
column16: but I'll go on to another question.  You and Mr. Mondale have already disagreed about what you had to say about recalling submarine-launched missiles. There's another
column17: a similar issue out there that relates to your -- it is said
column18: at least
column19: that you were unaware that the Soviet retaliatory power was based on land-based missiles. First
column21: if it is correct
column22: have you informed yourself in the meantime? And third
column23: is it even necessary for the President to be so intimately involved in strategic details?

column1: Yes
column2: this had to do with our disarmament talks. And the whole controversy about land missiles came up because we thought that the strategic nuclear weapons
column3: the most destabilizing are the land-based. You put your thumb on a button and somebody blows up 20 minutes later. So
column4: we thought that it would be simpler to negotiate first with those. And then we made it plain
column5: a second phase
column6: take up the submarine-launched or the airborne missiles. The Soviet Union
column7: to our surprise -- and not just mine -- made it plain when we brought this up that they placed
column8: they thought
column9: a greater reliance on the land-based missiles and
column10: therefore
column11: they wanted to take up all three. And we agreed. We said
column12: ""All right
column13: if that's what you want to do.'' But it was a surprise to us
column14: because they outnumbered us 64 to 36 in submarines and 20 percent more bombers capable of carrying nuclear missiles than we had. So
column15: why should we believe that they had placed that much more reliance on land-based?  But even after we gave in and said
column16: ""All right
column17: let's discuss it all
column18: '' they walked away from the table. We didn't.   The President's Age  Mr. Trewhitt. Mr. Mondale
column19: I'm going to hang in there. Should the President's age and stamina be an issue in the political campaign?

column1: No. And I have not made it an issue
column2: nor should it be. What's at issue here is the President's application of his authority to understand what a President must know to lead this nation
column3: secure our defense
column4: and make the decisions and the judgments that are necessary. A minute ago the President quoted Cicero
column5: I believe. I want to quote somebody a little closer to home
column6: Harry Truman. He said
column7: ""The buck stops here.'' We just heard the President's answer for the problems at the barracks in Lebanon
column8: where 241 marines were killed. What happened? First
column9: the Joint Chiefs of Staff went to the President
column10: said
column11: ""Don't put those troops there.'' They did it. And then 5 days before the troops were killed
column12: they went back to the President
column13: through the Secretary of Defense
column14: and said
column15: ""Please
column16: Mr. President
column17: take those troops out of there because we can't defend them.'' They didn't do it. And we know what happened.  After that
column18: once again
column19: our Embassy was exploded. This is the fourth time this has happened -- an identical attack
column21: despite warnings -- even public warnings -- from the terrorists. Who's in charge? Who's handling this matter? That's my main point.  Now
column22: on arms control
column23: we're completing 4 years. This is the first administration since the bomb went off that made no progress. We have an arms race underway instead.  A President has to lead his government or it won't be done. Different people with different views fight with each other. For 3\1/2\ years
column25: resisted tabling arms control proposals that had any hope of agreeing
column26: rebuked their negotiator in 1981 when he came close to an agreement
column28: on medium-range weapons. And we have this arms race underway. And a recent book that just came out by perhaps the Nation's most respected author in this field
column30: called ""Deadly Gambits
column31: '' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us
column32: both in terms of security and terms of arms control. That's why they call the President the Commander in Chief.  Good intentions
column33: I grant. But it takes more than that. You must be tough and smart.   The President's Leadership  Mr. Trewhitt. This question of leadership keeps arising in different forms in this discussion already. And the President
column35: has called you whining and vacillating
column36: among the more charitable phrases -- weak
column37: I believe. It is a question of leadership. And he has made the point that you have not repudiated some of the semidiplomatic activity of the Reverend Jackson
column38: particularly in Central America. Did you approve of his diplomatic activity? And are you prepared to repudiate him now?

column1: I read his statement the other day. I don't admire Fidel Castro at all. And I've said that. Che Guevara was a contemptible figure in civilization's history. I know the Cuban state as a police state
column2: and all my life I've worked in a way that demonstrates that. But Jesse Jackson is an independent person. I don't control him. And let's talk about people we do control. In the last debate
column3: \1\ (FOOTNOTE) the Vice President of the United States said that I said the marines had died shamefully and died in shame in Lebanon. I demanded an apology from Vice President Bush because I had
column4: instead
column5: honored these young men
column6: grieved for their families
column7: and think they were wonderful Americans that honored us all. What does the President have to say about taking responsibility for a Vice President who won't apologize for something like that?  (FOOTNOTE) \1\Mr. Mondale was referring to an earlier debate between George Bush and Geraldine Ferarro
column8: the Vice-Presidential candidates.

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale
column2: but I am in charge. And
column3: as a matter of fact
column4: we haven't avoided arms control talks with the Soviet Union. Very early in my administration I proposed -- and I think something that had never been proposed by any previous administration -- I proposed a total elimination of intermediate-range missiles
column5: where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe. When they protested that and suggested a smaller number
column6: perhaps
column7: I went along with that. The so-called negotiation that you said I walked out on was the so-called walk in the woods between one of our representatives and one of the Soviet Union
column8: and it wasn't me that turned it down
column9: the Soviet Union disavowed it.

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others
column2: but two that I want to cite tonight. One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book
column3: ""Deadly Gambits.'' The other is John Neuhaus
column4: who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country. Both said that this administration turned down the ""walk in the woods'' agreement first
column5: and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security. When Mr. Nitze
column6: a good negotiator
column7: returned
column8: he was rebuked
column9: and his boss was fired. This is the kind of leadership that we've had in this administration on the most deadly issue of our times. Now we have a runaway arms race. All they've got to show for 4 years in U.S.-Soviet relations is one meeting in the last weeks of an administration
column10: and nothing before.  They're tough negotiators
column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column6: Harry Truman. He said
column7: ""The buck stops here.'' We just heard the President's answer for the problems at the barracks in Lebanon
column8: where 241 marines were killed. What happened? First
column9: the Joint Chiefs of Staff went to the President
column10: said
column11: ""Don't put those troops there.'' They did it. And then 5 days before the troops were killed
column12: they went back to the President
column13: through the Secretary of Defense
column14: and said
column15: ""Please
column16: Mr. President
column17: take those troops out of there because we can't defend them.'' They didn't do it. And we know what happened.  After that
column18: once again
column19: our Embassy was exploded. This is the fourth time this has happened -- an identical attack
column21: despite warnings -- even public warnings -- from the terrorists. Who's in charge? Who's handling this matter? That's my main point.  Now
column22: on arms control
column23: we're completing 4 years. This is the first administration since the bomb went off that made no progress. We have an arms race underway instead.  A President has to lead his government or it won't be done. Different people with different views fight with each other. For 3\1/2\ years
column25: resisted tabling arms control proposals that had any hope of agreeing
column26: rebuked their negotiator in 1981 when he came close to an agreement
column28: on medium-range weapons. And we have this arms race underway. And a recent book that just came out by perhaps the Nation's most respected author in this field
column30: called ""Deadly Gambits
column31: '' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us
column32: both in terms of security and terms of arms control. That's why they call the President the Commander in Chief.  Good intentions
column33: I grant. But it takes more than that. You must be tough and smart.   The President's Leadership  Mr. Trewhitt. This question of leadership keeps arising in different forms in this discussion already. And the President
column35: has called you whining and vacillating
column36: among the more charitable phrases -- weak
column37: I believe. It is a question of leadership. And he has made the point that you have not repudiated some of the semidiplomatic activity of the Reverend Jackson
column38: particularly in Central America. Did you approve of his diplomatic activity? And are you prepared to repudiate him now?

column1: I read his statement the other day. I don't admire Fidel Castro at all. And I've said that. Che Guevara was a contemptible figure in civilization's history. I know the Cuban state as a police state
column2: and all my life I've worked in a way that demonstrates that. But Jesse Jackson is an independent person. I don't control him. And let's talk about people we do control. In the last debate
column3: \1\ (FOOTNOTE) the Vice President of the United States said that I said the marines had died shamefully and died in shame in Lebanon. I demanded an apology from Vice President Bush because I had
column4: instead
column5: honored these young men
column6: grieved for their families
column7: and think they were wonderful Americans that honored us all. What does the President have to say about taking responsibility for a Vice President who won't apologize for something like that?  (FOOTNOTE) \1\Mr. Mondale was referring to an earlier debate between George Bush and Geraldine Ferarro
column8: the Vice-Presidential candidates.

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale
column2: but I am in charge. And
column3: as a matter of fact
column4: we haven't avoided arms control talks with the Soviet Union. Very early in my administration I proposed -- and I think something that had never been proposed by any previous administration -- I proposed a total elimination of intermediate-range missiles
column5: where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe. When they protested that and suggested a smaller number
column6: perhaps
column7: I went along with that. The so-called negotiation that you said I walked out on was the so-called walk in the woods between one of our representatives and one of the Soviet Union
column8: and it wasn't me that turned it down
column9: the Soviet Union disavowed it.

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others
column2: but two that I want to cite tonight. One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book
column3: ""Deadly Gambits.'' The other is John Neuhaus
column4: who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country. Both said that this administration turned down the ""walk in the woods'' agreement first
column5: and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security. When Mr. Nitze
column6: a good negotiator
column7: returned
column8: he was rebuked
column9: and his boss was fired. This is the kind of leadership that we've had in this administration on the most deadly issue of our times. Now we have a runaway arms race. All they've got to show for 4 years in U.S.-Soviet relations is one meeting in the last weeks of an administration
column10: and nothing before.  They're tough negotiators
column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column4: and make the decisions and the judgments that are necessary. A minute ago the President quoted Cicero

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale

column5: where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe. When they protested that and suggested a smaller number

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others
column2: but two that I want to cite tonight. One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book
column3: ""Deadly Gambits.'' The other is John Neuhaus
column4: who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country. Both said that this administration turned down the ""walk in the woods'' agreement first
column5: and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security. When Mr. Nitze

column10: and nothing before.  They're tough negotiators
column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column28: on medium-range weapons. And we have this arms race underway. And a recent book that just came out by perhaps the Nation's most respected author in this field
column30: called ""Deadly Gambits
column31: '' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us
column32: both in terms of security and terms of arms control. That's why they call the President the Commander in Chief.  Good intentions
column33: I grant. But it takes more than that. You must be tough and smart.   The President's Leadership  Mr. Trewhitt. This question of leadership keeps arising in different forms in this discussion already. And the President
column35: has called you whining and vacillating
column36: among the more charitable phrases -- weak
column37: I believe. It is a question of leadership. And he has made the point that you have not repudiated some of the semidiplomatic activity of the Reverend Jackson
column38: particularly in Central America. Did you approve of his diplomatic activity? And are you prepared to repudiate him now?

column1: I read his statement the other day. I don't admire Fidel Castro at all. And I've said that. Che Guevara was a contemptible figure in civilization's history. I know the Cuban state as a police state
column2: and all my life I've worked in a way that demonstrates that. But Jesse Jackson is an independent person. I don't control him. And let's talk about people we do control. In the last debate
column3: \1\ (FOOTNOTE) the Vice President of the United States said that I said the marines had died shamefully and died in shame in Lebanon. I demanded an apology from Vice President Bush because I had
column4: instead
column5: honored these young men
column6: grieved for their families
column7: and think they were wonderful Americans that honored us all. What does the President have to say about taking responsibility for a Vice President who won't apologize for something like that?  (FOOTNOTE) \1\Mr. Mondale was referring to an earlier debate between George Bush and Geraldine Ferarro
column8: the Vice-Presidential candidates.

column1: Yes. I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale
column2: but I am in charge. And
column3: as a matter of fact
column4: we haven't avoided arms control talks with the Soviet Union. Very early in my administration I proposed -- and I think something that had never been proposed by any previous administration -- I proposed a total elimination of intermediate-range missiles
column5: where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe. When they protested that and suggested a smaller number
column6: perhaps
column7: I went along with that. The so-called negotiation that you said I walked out on was the so-called walk in the woods between one of our representatives and one of the Soviet Union
column8: and it wasn't me that turned it down
column9: the Soviet Union disavowed it.

column1: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others
column2: but two that I want to cite tonight. One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book
column3: ""Deadly Gambits.'' The other is John Neuhaus
column4: who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country. Both said that this administration turned down the ""walk in the woods'' agreement first
column5: and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security. When Mr. Nitze
column6: a good negotiator
column7: returned
column8: he was rebuked
column9: and his boss was fired. This is the kind of leadership that we've had in this administration on the most deadly issue of our times. Now we have a runaway arms race. All they've got to show for 4 years in U.S.-Soviet relations is one meeting in the last weeks of an administration
column10: and nothing before.  They're tough negotiators
column11: but all previous Presidents have made progress. This one has not.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no
column5: Mr. Mondale
column6: my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say
column7: ""Now
column8: are you willing to join us? Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- ""Here's what we can do. Now
column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world
column10: then we'll give you this one
column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column1: Well
column2: that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be. If they're space weapons
column3: I assume they'll be in space. [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons
column4: I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites. Now

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.

column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

' 3848.44']	['Mr Kalb, I think what has been hailed as something Im supposedly, as President, discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years, the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon, and so forth, and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true, that the prophecies are coming together that portend that', 'But no one knows whether Armageddon, those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow', 'So, I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon', 'Now, with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war, of course we would', 'But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world, in Europe and in Asia, I have made a statement to each one of them, and Ill repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought', 'And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage', 'But the deterrent  and thats what it is for  is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept, but propose that we research to see if there isnt a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles', 'And if such a defense could be found, wouldnt it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?', 'Strategic Defense Initiative', 'Why not?', 'What if we did  and I hope we can; were still researching  what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete?', 'There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive, a column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no
column5: Mr. Mondale
column6: my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say
column7: ""Now
column8: are you willing to join us? Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- ""Here's what we can do. Now
column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world
column10: then we'll give you this one
column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column1: Well
column2: that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be. If they're space weapons
column3: I assume they'll be in space. [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons
column4: I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites. Now
column5: this is the most dangerous technology that we possess. The Soviets try to spy on us
column6: steal this stuff. And to give them technology of this kind
column7: I disagree with. You haven't just accepted research
column8: Mr. President. You've set up a Strategic Defense Initiative
column9: an agency
column10: you're beginning to test
column11: you're talking about deploying
column12: you're asking for a budget of some $30 billion for this purpose. This is an arms escalation. And we will be better off
column13: far better off
column14: if we stop right now
column15: because we have more to lose in space then they do. If someday
column16: somebody comes along with an answer
column17: that's something else. But that there would be an answer in our lifetime is unimaginable.  Why do we start things that we know the Soviets will match and make us all less secure? That's what a President's for.
