column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no
column5: Mr. Mondale
column6: my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say
column7: ""Now
column8: are you willing to join us? Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- ""Here's what we can do. Now
column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world
column10: then we'll give you this one
column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column1: Well
column2: that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be. If they're space weapons
column3: I assume they'll be in space. [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons
column4: I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites. Now
column5: this is the most dangerous technology that we possess. The Soviets try to spy on us
column6: steal this stuff. And to give them technology of this kind
column7: I disagree with. You haven't just accepted research
column8: Mr. President. You've set up a Strategic Defense Initiative
column9: an agency
column10: you're beginning to test
column11: you're talking about deploying
column12: you're asking for a budget of some $30 billion for this purpose. This is an arms escalation. And we will be better off
column13: far better off
column14: if we stop right now
column15: because we have more to lose in space then they do. If someday
column16: somebody comes along with an answer
column17: that's something else. But that there would be an answer in our lifetime is unimaginable.  Why do we start things that we know the Soviets will match and make us all less secure? That's what a President's for.

column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years

column15: in Europe and in Asia

column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah

column7: ""Look

column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes

column3: once again

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no

column7: ""Now

column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world

column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column9: an agency

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no
column5: Mr. Mondale
column6: my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say
column7: ""Now
column8: are you willing to join us? Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- ""Here's what we can do. Now
column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world
column10: then we'll give you this one
column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column1: Well
column2: that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be. If they're space weapons
column3: I assume they'll be in space. [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons
column4: I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites. Now
column5: this is the most dangerous technology that we possess. The Soviets try to spy on us
column6: steal this stuff. And to give them technology of this kind
column7: I disagree with. You haven't just accepted research
column8: Mr. President. You've set up a Strategic Defense Initiative
column9: an agency
column10: you're beginning to test
column11: you're talking about deploying
column12: you're asking for a budget of some $30 billion for this purpose. This is an arms escalation. And we will be better off
column13: far better off
column14: if we stop right now
column15: because we have more to lose in space then they do. If someday
column16: somebody comes along with an answer
column17: that's something else. But that there would be an answer in our lifetime is unimaginable.  Why do we start things that we know the Soviets will match and make us all less secure? That's what a President's for.

column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no

column7: ""Now

column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon

column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said

column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now

column16: because maybe someday

column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no

column7: ""Now

column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world

column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said

column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says

column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 6)	" Mr. Kalb
column4: I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly
column5: as President
column6: discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years
column7: the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon
column8: and so forth
column9: and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true
column10: that the prophecies are coming together that portend that. But no one knows whether Armageddon
column11: those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow. So
column12: I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon. Now
column13: with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war
column14: of course we would. But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world
column15: in Europe and in Asia
column16: I have made a statement to each one of them
column17: and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.  But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept
column18: but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles. And if such a defense could be found
column19: wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?   Strategic Defense Initiative

column1: Why not? What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete? There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive
column2: a counterweapon. But suppose we came up with that? Now
column3: some people have said
column4: ""Ah
column5: that would make war imminent
column6: because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.'' But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do? Say
column7: ""Look
column8: here's what we can do. We'll even give it to you. Now
column9: will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid
column10: all of us
column11: of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?'' I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.

column1: First of all
column2: let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced
column3: the most dangerous
column4: the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union. We have had for many years
column5: understandably
column6: a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us. And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers
column7: our most advanced engineering. And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is
column8: in my opinion
column9: a total non-STARTer. I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all. Now
column10: what's wrong with Star Wars? There's nothing wrong with the theory of it. If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt
column11: I suppose it's a good idea. But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that
column12: that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems
column13: each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project. It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.  The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind. And they always do. We don't get behind. They won't get behind. And that's been the tragic story of the arms race. We have more at stake in space satellites than they do. If we could stop
column14: right now
column15: the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument
column16: because maybe someday
column17: somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time
column18: in their crude state
column19: would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.  One final point. The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is
column21: we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war. That's dead wrong. There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers. It might be an oil fire
column22: it might be a jet exhaust
column23: the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.  Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war? [Applause]   Nuclear Freeze

column1: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement. I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day. I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported. That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes. Now
column2: why do I support the freeze? Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure. It's more difficult to defend this nation. It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war. This administration
column3: by going into the Star Wars system
column4: is going to add a dangerous new escalation. We have to be tough on the Soviet Union
column5: but I think the American people -- --

column1: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Yes
column2: my rebuttal
column3: once again
column4: is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no
column5: Mr. Mondale
column6: my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say
column7: ""Now
column8: are you willing to join us? Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- ""Here's what we can do. Now
column9: if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world
column10: then we'll give you this one
column11: so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat . . . .'' But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist. I said
column12: and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me
column13: that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon. And suddenly somebody says
column14: ""Oh
column15: it's got to be up there
column16: and it's Star Wars
column17: '' and so forth. I don't know what it would be
column18: but if we can come up with one
column19: I think the world will be better off.

column1: Well
column2: that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be. If they're space weapons
column3: I assume they'll be in space. [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons
column4: I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites. Now
column5: this is the most dangerous technology that we possess. The Soviets try to spy on us
column6: steal this stuff. And to give them technology of this kind
column7: I disagree with. You haven't just accepted research
column8: Mr. President. You've set up a Strategic Defense Initiative
column9: an agency
column10: you're beginning to test
column11: you're talking about deploying
column12: you're asking for a budget of some $30 billion for this purpose. This is an arms escalation. And we will be better off
column13: far better off
column14: if we stop right now
column15: because we have more to lose in space then they do. If someday
column16: somebody comes along with an answer
column17: that's something else. But that there would be an answer in our lifetime is unimaginable.  Why do we start things that we know the Soviets will match and make us all less secure? That's what a President's for.

column2: '21Oct'
column3: 7)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: we have a vast range of technology and weaponry right now that provides all the bargaining chips that we need. And I support the air launch cruise missile
column5: the ground launch cruise missile
column6: the Pershing missile
column7: the Trident submarine
column8: the D - 5 submarine
column9: Stealth technology
column10: the Midgetman -- we have a whole range of technology. Why I disagree with the MX is that it's a sitting duck. It'll draw an attack. It puts a hair-trigger
column11: and it is a dangerous
column12: destabilizing weapon. And the B - 1 is similarly to be opposed
column13: because for 15 years the Soviet Union has been preparing to meet the B - 1. The Secretary of Defense himself said it would be a suicide mission if it were built. Instead
column14: I want to build the Midgetman
column15: which is mobile and thus less vulnerable
column16: contributing to stability
column17: and a weapon that will give us security and contribute to an incentive for arms control. That's why I'm for Stealth technology
column18: to build a Stealth bomber -- which I've supported for years -- that can penetrate the Soviet air defense system without any hope that they can perceive where it is because their radar system is frustrated. In other words
column19: a President has to make choices. This makes us stronger.  The final point is that we can use this money that we save on these weapons to spend on things that we really need. Our conventional strength in Europe is under strength. We need to strengthen that in order to assure our Western allies of our presence there
column21: but also to diminish and reduce the likelihood of a commencement of a war and the use of nuclear weapons. It's in this way
column22: by making wise choices
column23: that we're stronger
column24: we enhance the chances of arms control. Every President until this one has been able to do it
column25: and this nation -- or the world is more dangerous as a result.   Nuclear Freeze

column1: I will not agree to any arms control agreement
column2: including a freeze
column3: that's not verifiable. Let's take your warhead principle. The warhead principle -- there have been counting rules for years. Whenever a weapon is tested we count the number of warheads on it
column4: and whenever that warhead is used we count that number of warheads
column5: whether they have that number or less on it
column6: or not. These are standard rules. I will not agree to any production restrictions -- or agreements
column7: unless we have the ability to verify those agreements. I don't trust the Russians. I believe that every agreement we reach must be verifiable
column8: and I will not agree to anything that we cannot tell every day. In other words
column9: we've got to be tough. But in order to stop this arms madness
column10: we've got to push ahead with tough negotiations that are verifiable so that we know the Soviets are agreeing and living up to their agreement.  Support for U.S. Allies

column1: Morton
column2: I did criticize the President because of our undercutting of what was a stalwart ally -- the Shah of Iran. And I am not at all convinced that he was that far out of line with his people or that they wanted that to happen. The Shah had done our bidding and carried our load in the Middle East for quite some time
column3: and I did think that it was a blot on our record that we let him down. Have things gotten better? The Shah
column4: whatever he might have done
column5: was building low-cost housing
column6: had taken land away from the Mullahs and was distributing it to the peasants so they could be landowners -- things of that kind. But we turned it over to a maniacal fanatic who has slaughtered thousands and thousands of people
column7: calling it executions. The matter of Somoza -- no
column8: I never defended Somoza. And
column9: as a matter of fact
column10: the previous administration stood by and so did I -- not that I could have done anything in my position at that time -- but for this revolution to take place. And the promise of the revolution was democracy
column11: human rights
column12: free labor unions
column13: free press. And then
column14: just as Castro had done in Cuba
column15: the Sandinistas ousted the other parties to the revolution. Many of them are now the contras. They exiled some
column16: they jailed some
column17: they murdered some. And they installed a Marxist-Leninist totalitarian government.  And what I have to say about this is
column18: many times -- and this has to do with the Philippines
column19: also
column20: I know there are things there in the Philippines that do not look good to us from the standpoint right now of democratic rights
column21: but what is the alternative? It is a large Communist movement to take over the Philippines. They have been our friend since their inception as a nation.  And I think that we've had enough of a record of letting -- under the guise of revolution -- someone that we thought was a little more right than we would be
column22: letting that person go
column23: and then winding up with totalitarianism
column25: as the alternative. And I think that we're better off
column26: for example with the Philippines
column27: of trying to retain our friendship and help them right the wrongs we see
column28: rather than throwing them to the wolves and then facing a Communist power in the Pacific.

column1: Well
column2: as I say
column3: we have to look at what an overthrow there would mean and what the government would be that would follow. And there is every evidence
column4: every indication that that government would be hostile to the United States. And that would be a severe blow to our abilities there in the Pacific.

column1: Perhaps in no area do we disagree more than this administration's policies on human rights. I went to the Philippines as Vice President
column2: pressed for human rights
column3: called for the release of Aquino
column4: and made progress that had been stalled on both the Subic and the Clark airfield bases. What explains this administration cozying up to the Argentine dictators after they took over? Fortunately
column5: a democracy took over
column6: but this nation was embarrassed by this current administration's adoption of their policies.  What happens in South Africa
column7: where
column8: for example
column9: the Nobel Prize winner
column10: 2 days ago
column11: said this administration is seen as working with the oppressive government of South Africa. That hurts this nation. We need to stand for human rights. We need to make it clear we're for human liberty. National security and human rights must go together. But this administration time and time again has lost its way in this field.

column1: Well
column2: the invasion of Afghanistan didn't take place on our watch. I have described what has happened in Iran
column3: and we weren't here then either. I don't think that our record of human rights can be assailed. I think that we have observed
column4: ourselves
column5: and have done our best to see that human rights are extended throughout the world. Mr. Mondale has recently announced a plan of his to get the democracies together and to work with the whole world to turn to democracy. And I was glad to hear him say that
column6: because that's what we've been doing ever since I announced to the British Parliament that I thought we should do this.  Human rights are not advanced when
column7: at the same time
column8: you then stand back and say
column9: ""Whoops
column10: we didn't know the gun was loaded
column11: '' and you have another totalitarian power on your hands.

column3: 7)	" No. As a matter of fact
column4: we have a vast range of technology and weaponry right now that provides all the bargaining chips that we need. And I support the air launch cruise missile
column5: the ground launch cruise missile
column6: the Pershing missile
column7: the Trident submarine
column8: the D - 5 submarine
column9: Stealth technology
column10: the Midgetman -- we have a whole range of technology. Why I disagree with the MX is that it's a sitting duck. It'll draw an attack. It puts a hair-trigger
column11: and it is a dangerous
column12: destabilizing weapon. And the B - 1 is similarly to be opposed
column13: because for 15 years the Soviet Union has been preparing to meet the B - 1. The Secretary of Defense himself said it would be a suicide mission if it were built. Instead
column14: I want to build the Midgetman
column15: which is mobile and thus less vulnerable
column16: contributing to stability
column17: and a weapon that will give us security and contribute to an incentive for arms control. That's why I'm for Stealth technology
column18: to build a Stealth bomber -- which I've supported for years -- that can penetrate the Soviet air defense system without any hope that they can perceive where it is because their radar system is frustrated. In other words
column19: a President has to make choices. This makes us stronger.  The final point is that we can use this money that we save on these weapons to spend on things that we really need. Our conventional strength in Europe is under strength. We need to strengthen that in order to assure our Western allies of our presence there
column21: but also to diminish and reduce the likelihood of a commencement of a war and the use of nuclear weapons. It's in this way
column22: by making wise choices
column23: that we're stronger
column24: we enhance the chances of arms control. Every President until this one has been able to do it
column25: and this nation -- or the world is more dangerous as a result.   Nuclear Freeze

column1: I will not agree to any arms control agreement
column2: including a freeze
column3: that's not verifiable. Let's take your warhead principle. The warhead principle -- there have been counting rules for years. Whenever a weapon is tested we count the number of warheads on it
column4: and whenever that warhead is used we count that number of warheads
column5: whether they have that number or less on it
column6: or not. These are standard rules. I will not agree to any production restrictions -- or agreements
column7: unless we have the ability to verify those agreements. I don't trust the Russians. I believe that every agreement we reach must be verifiable
column8: and I will not agree to anything that we cannot tell every day. In other words
column9: we've got to be tough. But in order to stop this arms madness
column10: we've got to push ahead with tough negotiations that are verifiable so that we know the Soviets are agreeing and living up to their agreement.  Support for U.S. Allies

column1: Morton
column2: I did criticize the President because of our undercutting of what was a stalwart ally -- the Shah of Iran. And I am not at all convinced that he was that far out of line with his people or that they wanted that to happen. The Shah had done our bidding and carried our load in the Middle East for quite some time
column3: and I did think that it was a blot on our record that we let him down. Have things gotten better? The Shah
column4: whatever he might have done
column5: was building low-cost housing
column6: had taken land away from the Mullahs and was distributing it to the peasants so they could be landowners -- things of that kind. But we turned it over to a maniacal fanatic who has slaughtered thousands and thousands of people
column7: calling it executions. The matter of Somoza -- no
column8: I never defended Somoza. And
column9: as a matter of fact
column10: the previous administration stood by and so did I -- not that I could have done anything in my position at that time -- but for this revolution to take place. And the promise of the revolution was democracy
column11: human rights
column12: free labor unions
column13: free press. And then
column14: just as Castro had done in Cuba
column15: the Sandinistas ousted the other parties to the revolution. Many of them are now the contras. They exiled some
column16: they jailed some
column17: they murdered some. And they installed a Marxist-Leninist totalitarian government.  And what I have to say about this is
column18: many times -- and this has to do with the Philippines
column19: also
column20: I know there are things there in the Philippines that do not look good to us from the standpoint right now of democratic rights
column21: but what is the alternative? It is a large Communist movement to take over the Philippines. They have been our friend since their inception as a nation.  And I think that we've had enough of a record of letting -- under the guise of revolution -- someone that we thought was a little more right than we would be
column22: letting that person go
column23: and then winding up with totalitarianism
column25: as the alternative. And I think that we're better off
column26: for example with the Philippines
column27: of trying to retain our friendship and help them right the wrongs we see
column28: rather than throwing them to the wolves and then facing a Communist power in the Pacific.

column1: Well
column2: as I say
column3: we have to look at what an overthrow there would mean and what the government would be that would follow. And there is every evidence
column4: every indication that that government would be hostile to the United States. And that would be a severe blow to our abilities there in the Pacific.

column1: Perhaps in no area do we disagree more than this administration's policies on human rights. I went to the Philippines as Vice President
column2: pressed for human rights
column3: called for the release of Aquino
column4: and made progress that had been stalled on both the Subic and the Clark airfield bases. What explains this administration cozying up to the Argentine dictators after they took over? Fortunately
column5: a democracy took over
column6: but this nation was embarrassed by this current administration's adoption of their policies.  What happens in South Africa
column7: where
column8: for example
column9: the Nobel Prize winner
column10: 2 days ago
column11: said this administration is seen as working with the oppressive government of South Africa. That hurts this nation. We need to stand for human rights. We need to make it clear we're for human liberty. National security and human rights must go together. But this administration time and time again has lost its way in this field.

column1: Well
column2: the invasion of Afghanistan didn't take place on our watch. I have described what has happened in Iran
column3: and we weren't here then either. I don't think that our record of human rights can be assailed. I think that we have observed
column4: ourselves
column5: and have done our best to see that human rights are extended throughout the world. Mr. Mondale has recently announced a plan of his to get the democracies together and to work with the whole world to turn to democracy. And I was glad to hear him say that
column6: because that's what we've been doing ever since I announced to the British Parliament that I thought we should do this.  Human rights are not advanced when
column7: at the same time
column8: you then stand back and say
column9: ""Whoops
column10: we didn't know the gun was loaded
column11: '' and you have another totalitarian power on your hands.
